awd_titl_txt: CCRI: ENS: Collaborative Research: Enhancing R for Scalability and Deployment
awd_abstract_narration:
Data analytics software systems are integral to the fabric of science. The ability to acquire, process, and analyze complex data is at the core of disciplines that range from high-energy physics, astronomy, chemistry, and biology. While scientists can exploit repositories of tools optimized and refined over the years, significant new challenges are posed by the rapidly evolving characteristics of modern scientific datasets. New analyzes rely on interactive computer programming languages that are open source and that allow rapid, interactive, data exploration. This project aims to strengthen and enhance the R software infrastructure. R is the language and environment with the largest collection of free and reusable data analytics software packages. This project will help R adapt to the evolving needs of researchers in diverse fields. The technical enhancements, embodied by new and updated software components, will open opportunities for researchers to contribute to the community infrastructure and enable a number of new research directions building on R as a platform. Lastly, this project's engagement and outreach plans address both outreach to user- and developer-communities and create a pipeline of future contributors.

The proposed enhancements to the R infrastructure address four key needs and are enablers to research. In terms of scalability, the R environment needs support for both scaling up computation to support out-of-core data and scaling down computations with compact data formats. In terms of deployment, the R language needs to support multiple deployment formats. This project envisions addressing this need by supporting separate compilation of a subset of R to both native binaries and to WebAssembly where the former would have the benefit of performance and could be linked as a library, while the latter would benefit from the ubiquity of JavaScript, running in any browser. In terms of robustness, the R language needs tools to verify and validate native code. This project will extend existing checkers with a detailed understanding of R semantics and to automatically check for a variety of errors statically, and optionally insert run-time checks for cases which cannot be proved statically. In terms of community outreach, there is a need for a pipeline for training potential R developers. This project will create educational material and operate two yearly summer schools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this research is to strengthen and enhance the R software infrastructure. R is a data analysis language and environment with a large collection of community-contributed free and reusable data analytics software packages. The extensions developed in this research will help R to adapt to the evolving needs of researchers in diverse fields. The technical enhancements, incorporated in current and upcoming releases of R, will enable a number of exciting new research directions building on R as a platform and will also open opportunities for researchers to contribute to the community infrastructure, Furthermore, our engagement and outreach work targeting both user and developer communities will help create a pipeline of future contributors to the project.

The intellectual contribution of this work consists of enhancements to the R infrastructure in four areas: Improving performace of the parallel computing infrastructure, exploring strategies for compiling the R language for more efficient execution, syntax improvements to help improve the efficiency of users of the language, and adapting R to take advantage of new hardware platforms.

The broader impact resulting from the research is to improve the ability of researchers, instructors, and other users of statistical methodology to eﬀectively apply this methodology in scientiﬁc research and teaching. This is accomplished by making available results of the research as enhancements and additions to the R open source statistical software system. This system is widely used in teaching, research, and industry, and is a strong inﬂuence on other software projects, including both research software and commercial software.
